item.title: Nintendo 64 Mature Switch Online Collection Explained
item.description:
Highlights

  • Nintendo Switch still has surprises with new games like Mario & Zelda announced in recent Nintendo Direct.
  • Expansion Pack for Switch Online adds Mature Collection, including Turok and Perfect Dark, for 17+ players.
  • More mature N64 games likely to join Expansion Pack's Mature Collection, like Conker's Bad Fur Day and Resident Evil 2.

While the Nintendo Switch is definitely nearing the end of its life, there are still plenty of tricks up its sleeve, and the recent Nintendo Direct confirmed that. The 40-minute-long livestream revealed a plethora of new video games coming from both Nintendo's first-party studios and its third-party collaborators. A new Mario & Luigi game, a Zelda-led Legend of Zelda game, and Metroid Prime 4 's triumphant return were all some of the biggest announcements to come out of today's Nintendo Direct, but there were plenty of other noteworthy reveals.

Over the last few years, Nintendo has continued to add value to its Switch Online subscription service by adding new games to its library. Back in October 2021, Nintendo added the Expansion Pack to its Switch Online service, a premium tier that offered Nintendo 64, Sega Genesis, and Game Boy Advance games to the ever-growing library. Today, it was announced that Nintendo Switch Online's Expansion Pack would be receiving a new slew of games, including two titles that belong to an all-new 'Mature Collection'.

Related
What Are Your Thoughts on The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom?

The next installment in the iconic Zelda franchise puts players in control of the titular character. Using Echoes to spawn objects have us excited to test the limits of our creativity to overcome the game's challenges and puzzles.

Two N64 Classics Are Coming to Switch Via Its 'Mature Collection'

Turok and Perfect Dark Are Coming to The Nintendo Switch Online Expansion Pack

In today's Nintendo Direct, it was announced that two highly requested Nintendo 64 games are being added to Nintendo Switch Online's Expansion Pack, but rather than appear in the same app as previously released titles like Super Mario 64 and Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time , these two titles are only available in a brand new 'Mature Collection' app, designed specifically to house retro games with a 17+ Mature ESRB rating.

In its first wave, the Nintendo Switch Online Expansion Pack's Mature Collection has added just two games, Turok: Dinosaur Hunter , and Perfect Dark . The former is a 1997 first-person shooter based on the Turok Valiant Comics series, where players take control of the titular Native American time-traveling warrior as he battles dinosaurs and hostile alien forces in an attempt to stop the evil overlord known as The Campaigner. Turok technically released a few months before the groundbreaking GoldenEye 007 , so it's definitely worth checking out for anyone interested in the history of first-person shooters.

Rare's 2000 classic Perfect Dark is the other title that's come to the Nintendo Switch Online Expansion Pack's Mature Collection. Seen as a spiritual successor to GoldenEye , Perfect Dark is a first-person shooter that sees players take control of super spy Joanna Dark as she attempts to foil a mysterious extraterrestrial capitalist plot. With the Perfect Dark reboot reappearing in spectacular fashion at the recent Xbox Showcase, Nintendo's timing with this Expansion Pack launch is impeccable.

Turok and Perfect Dark Pave the Way for More Mature Expansion Pack Games

Being an entirely separate app, it seems very likely that this is only the beginning for the Nintendo Switch Online Expansion Pack's Mature Collection. There are a ton of classic Mature-rated N64 games that deserve a port to the Switch. The beloved Rare cult classic Conker's Bad Fur Day should be an obvious pick for Nintendo's Mature Collection, with it being surprisingly difficult to play in its original form due to inflated prices of the original N64 cartridge. The same can be said for the original N64 version of Resident Evil 2 , which would be great to see as well.

item.title: Fable 4's Humphry Explained
item.description:
Highlights

  • Fable's latest trailer introduces Humphry, a retired hero and key character who may play a larger role in the game than initially anticipated.
  • Humphry's past ties to Fable's villain suggest he may act as a mentor to the new protagonist, offering guidance and valuable skills throughout the story while warning them not to end up like his previous student.
  • With a deep history and important connections, Humphry could potentially be one of the most pivotal characters in Fable, shaping the player's journey.

Four years after its announcement and one year since its first gameplay trailer, Playground Games' upcoming action RPG Fable received another exclusive look at its story and gameplay during the Xbox Games Showcase. At this point, it's still unclear whether Fable will follow in the footsteps of its predecessors when it comes to gameplay and tone, as it seems to be an entirely different take on the series and its most explicit details have yet to be disclosed. Even so, what has been revealed so far has shown Fable to have full comprehension of its fantasy roots, as well as its characters and their exaggerated designs.

While Fable 's protagonist has been at the height of discussion and debate surrounding the game, another character was introduced in the latest trailer which has sparked even more conversation. Humphry, who has taken on the job of narrator in Fable 's official trailer, is a mysterious character who may end up playing a fairly prominent role in the game. Based on the context of the trailer and what Humphry reveals about himself and the game's protagonist, players can likely expect him to make regular appearances and function as a pivotal part of the player's journey through Fable 's story.

Fable's Humphry May Play a Larger Role Than It Seems

Humphry Is a Retired Hero Who Has a History With Fable's Villain

In all respects, Humphry is the star of Fable 's most recent trailer, giving fans the first look at a man who, by his own account, was once the greatest hero in all of Albion. While he doesn't explicitly mention it, Humphry is retired ahead of Fable 's story, having once graced the lands of Albion with his heroic presence only to apparently now be drinking away the remainder of his days and telling tales of old heroes. However, Fable 's story sees Humphry forced out of retirement, as a new threat has arisen in the form of a heroine he once had close ties with.

Prior to the events of Fable , Humphry took in a very powerful heroine when she had nowhere else to go. During their time together, the heroine grew to be incredibly strong, allowing all of her power to get to her head. Unfortunately, she wound up making the wrong choices and became the villain who now threatens Albion. In the latest trailer for the game, Fable 's protagonist approaches Humphry and simply says, "Humphry, she's back." Shortly thereafter, Humphry and the protagonist are seen coming face-to-face with who is presumably this heroine Humphry once knew.

Humphry Could Play the Role of Mentor in Fable

While very little has been revealed about Humphry's past and present, it can be assumed that he will play the role of mentor in Fable . This role was previously filled by characters like the Guildmaster of the Heroes Guild and Theresa in past Fable titles, and it's likely Humphry could help players in the same ways that they did — by teaching them new skills, guiding them through combat, and giving them a general overview of life as a hero or heroine in Albion. Based on what has been shown so far, it seems very probable that Humphry will step into this role, as he is even shown guiding Fable 's protagonist to “the most exclusive club in all of Albion” and then handing her a sword in the game's latest trailer.

Since Humphry has such a deep history with Fable 's primary antagonist, it's likely he will receive extensive character development throughout the game's story. This preemptively makes him one of Fable 's most important characters — perhaps even more so than the protagonist. As someone who is presumably the protagonist's mentor and an old friend to Fable 's villain, Humphry may play one of the game's most pivotal roles.

item.title: Capcom Has Bad News for Xbox Fans
item.description:
Highlights

  • Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics will not be available on Xbox, causing disappointment among Xbox gamers.
  • Fans expressed their displeasure on social media platforms over Capcom's decision to skip the Microsoft brand entirely.
  • The absence of Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection on Xbox remains a mystery, sparking backlash and controversy among fans.

Capcom fans are reacting to the news that the Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics collection might not be available on Xbox. During this week’s Nintendo Direct June 2024 showcase, gamers were taken by surprise with the reveal of a Marvel vs. Capcom collection, featuring no less than seven of Capcom’s most popular licensed crossover titles. Given that most of the classic Marvel vs Capcom games have spent the past decade or so in limbo, this announcement was met with much adulation from the fighting game community that had lobbied so hard to get them on modern consoles.

Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics will do exactly that when it launches later this year, at least when it comes to the Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, and Steam. Xbox gamers were quick to notice that neither the Xbox One nor the Xbox Series X/S were mentioned during the recent Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics announcement, causing much confusion and backlash among owners of those consoles. Capcom has yet to give any official reason for not releasing its new Marvel vs. Capcom compilation on Xbox, and many have been left scratching their heads since the similar Ace Attorney Investigations Collection will be available on Xbox One.

All across social media, Xbox gamers who had been looking forward to Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics have been voicing their displeasure at Capcom for skipping the Microsoft brand entirely, as reported by IGN. For example, a Reddit user on r/Xbox commented on the subject’s designated post that while they own a Nintendo Switch, they prefer to play their fighting games on Xbox using a classic-style arcade stick – something they won’t be able to do with the new Marvel vs Capcom collection. Meanwhile, the phrase “No Xbox” has been trending on Twitter, with users like Keith Garlington and Bella_Drive expressing their disappointment at the news.

Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection’s Xbox Snub Sparks Backlash

Other social media users, such as Jawmuncher on Twitter, have tried to come up with an explanation for why Capcom has decided to forgo releasing Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics on Xbox while still launching other upcoming titles on the system. They think it might have something to do with the running theory that Capcom’s proprietary MT Framework engine no longer works on Xbox One, hence why games like Mega Man Battle Network Legacy Collection and the Monster Hunter Stories series also skipped the console.

This wouldn’t make Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics not launching on Xbox any less of a disappointment for fans of the series, especially given the rich history Marvel vs Capcom has with Microsoft’s consoles. The original version of Marvel vs Capcom 2 was ported to Xbox alongside the PS2 back in 2002, and subsequent sequels and rereleases have always been available on the current Xbox system of the time. Capcom’s reason for leaving Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics off Xbox is still a mystery, but it has turned what would have been an undisputed victory for the fighting game community into another source of controversy.

item.title: Marvel's Spider-Man 2: All Suits (& How to Unlock Them)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Base Game Suits for Miles Morales in Spider-Man 2 (& How to Unlock Them)
  • All Base Game Peter Parker Suits in Spider-Man 2 (& How to Unlock Them)
  • Digital Deluxe Suits
  • Hellfire Gala and Fly N' Fresh Suit Pack
  • June 18 Update Suits

Suits are back in Marvel's Spider-Man 2 , and there are dozens to unlock for Peter and Miles. These suits not only call back to past adventures of the dual protagonists in Insomniac's series of games but also to other aspects of Spider-Man throughout Marvel's history.

Spider-Man 2 players will start the game with the iconic suit for both heroes, but as they level up and experience the main story, more and more costumes will be unlocked. There are also a couple of suits that can only be obtained by completing certain side activities. In this guide, we'll show off all the suits in Spider-Man 2 for Peter and Miles .

Updated on June 19, 2024: We've updated our suits post for Spider-Man 2 with eight more costumes added as part of the free June 18 patch from Insomniac Games.

Digital Deluxe Suits

Not listed in the tables above, there are five additional suits for Miles Morales and Peter Parker (10 in total). But these suits are only available to those who have purchased the game's Deluxe edition for $10 more. The suits are as follows:

  • Peter's Deluxe Edition Suits
    • Tactical Suit
    • Aurantia Suit
    • 25th Century Suit
    • Stone Monkey Suit
    • Apunkalyptic Suit

  • Miles' Deluxe Edition Suits
    • Biomechanical Suit
    • Tokusatsu Suit
    • Encoded Suit
    • Red Spectre Suit
    • Agimat Suit

Hellfire Gala and Fly N' Fresh Suit Pack

As part of an update released in March 2024, there are four more suits players can unlock for Peter and Miles (two for each). There are the Hellfire Gala suits that comes as a free cosmetic with the latest update and then there's the Fly suit for Peter and the Fresh Suit for Miles. The latter two suits are part of a collaboration with Gameheads.

For $4.99, players can get two neon-soaked suits, ten photo mode stickers, and two photo mode frames. The entire purchase of the DLC pack will be donated to Gameheads until April 5, 2024. After that, the suits will be available at no additional cost. For those wondering what the money is being donated towards, Gamehead's mission is to "empower low-income youth and youth of color to thrive in the games industry."

June 18 Update Suits

As part of a free update for Marvel's Spider-Man 2 , there are eight new suits for players to equip on Miles and Peter. You can check out the list of suits below, as well as images for each one:

  • Miles' Suits
    • Metro Suit
    • Ginga Suit
    • Animated Suit
    • Uptown Pride Suit

  • Peter's Suits
    • Into the Spider-Verse Suit
    • Last Stand Suit
    • Motorchic Suit
    • Fluro Suit

item.title: PSP Games With Graphics That Have Aged The Best
item.description:
Highlights

  • The PlayStation Portable was a successful handheld console that had a great library of games, showcasing its strengths and impressive graphics.
  • Some underrated gems on the PSP include Prince of Persia: The Forgotten Sands and The Godfather: Mob Wars , which still have impressive visuals to this day.
  • Other notable games on the PSP include Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories , Crisis Core: Final Fantasy 7, and Persona 3 Portable , all of which utilized the PSP's hardware well and still look great.

The PlayStation Portable is one of the most popular and beloved consoles of all time. It was an instant hit upon launch, featuring a wealth of excellent titles that players still remember fondly to this day. The fact that this handheld console managed to be a success despite facing competition from the king of handheld gaming, Nintendo, speaks volumes when it comes to just how impressive this console's sales numbers really were.

It's a shame that the PlayStation Vita never reached these heights of success, although some people point the finger at Sony for focusing solely on their home consoles and not giving this console the support it deserved. After all, the PSP was littered with numerous amazing games, with the titles listed below being particularly notable for still having an impressive level of graphical fidelity to this day.

Updated on June 19th, 2024, by Ritwik Mitra: The PlayStation Portable is one of the best handheld video game consoles of its era, and it's a shame that the PlayStation never really bothered to develop more portable consoles after the failure of the PlayStation Vita. The PSP featured a massive library of amazing games that players absolutely loved, with these titles doing a great job of working around the hardware limitations of the console. In fact, some of the best PSP games have aged surprisingly well, with their graphics being more than palatable to this day, and a few more of those games are now included on this list in its latest update.

15 Silent Hill: Shattered Memories

A Great Silent Hill Game That Looks Amazing On The PSP

Most people would argue that a true horror game doesn't give players any way to defend themselves against the monsters or psychos pursuing them. This is precisely why so many people love Silent Hill: Shattered Memories despite its many problems, because the game's unique storytelling approach, along with a clever retelling of the first game's narrative, make for a great time.

The game was initially released on the Wii before being ported to the PSP. Sure, the graphics had to be reduced in quality to make it run on the portable console's hardware, but the game still looks gorgeous and is one of the better looking games on the PlayStation Portable that fans will love even now.

14 Killzone: Liberation

A Third-Person Shooter That Pushes The PSP's Visual Fidelity To Its Limits

The Killzone series doesn't really get a lot of time in the limelight anymore, and fans can only hope that Sony gives this title the comeback it deserves. While the majority of titles in this series are first-person shooters, this PSP entry went a different route with a third-person perspective instead. The graphical fidelity of this title was one aspect that was praised to the roof, and it still holds up.

The visuals are great all on their own. Meanwhile, the gameplay makes the most of the PSP's control scheme to let players tackle some tense missions as they save hostages and gather intel while fighting artificially enhanced soldiers known as the Helghast. It's easily one of the best PlayStation Portable games players can check out, third-person shooter or otherwise, and it does almost everything right without any major flaws standing out.

13 Prince Of Persia: The Forgotten Sands

A 2.5D Sidescroller With Amazing Graphics

With the Prince of Persia movie coming out in 2010, Ubisoft decided to cash in on its hype by releasing the first game in the main series for many years. Assassin's Creed had taken over from the ashes of the series, but Forgotten Sands promised to bring the Prince back to the realm of relevancy once again. Unfortunately, the rather uninspired nature of this game on main consoles led to most people forgetting about a title that didn't really leave a lasting impact on fans.

However, the version of this title on the PSP was a gem that fans absolutely loved. The 2.5D sidescroller was a blast to play through and allowed players to utilize all of the Prince's signature tricks in a game that was easily one of the PSP's most underrated gems that deserved more time in the spotlight, with its visuals still looking pretty decent to this day.

12 The Godfather: Mob Wars

Become A Gangster In This Iconic Franchise With Some Amazing Graphics To Boot

  • Platforms : PSP
  • Release Date : September 2006
  • Developer : Page 44 Studios
  • Genre : Third-Person Action

Most people aren't aware that there's a game based on The Godfather on the PSP . The Godfather is a game that fans of titles with boundless crime should definitely check out, mainly because of how fun this game is despite seeming like a cash grab with an established IP's name slapped on it.

The game was originally released on major consoles, with the PSP re-release coming soon after. While it lacks the open-world element from the parent release, The Godfather: Mob Wars is a great accompaniment to the movie and allows players to live out the fantasy of being a gangster in this universe while working for the Corleone family.

11 Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories

The 3D GTA Engine At The Time Continues To Look Charming To This Day

The 3D GTA games released on the PSP were pretty great in their own right, allowing players to roam around familiar locales while experiencing completely new stories. Two games were released that adopted this format, with both Liberty City Stories and Vice City Stories doing a great job of letting players enjoy a full-fledged GTA game on a portable console.

Vice City Stories is considered by many to be the superior title, and understandably so. The game's rendition of Miami feels as fresh as ever, and players will have a great time mowing down their enemies as Vic Vance.

10 Crisis Core: Final Fantasy 7

An Excellent Addition To The Final Fantasy 7 Canon With Excellent Visuals

The recent ground-up remaster of Crisis Core: Final Fantasy 7 has been nothing short of incredible. However, while this glow-up has been received fairly well, there's no denying that the look of the original Crisis Core was also pretty great in its own right.

This prequel took a look at Zack's adventures as a member of SOLDIER before his untimely death. It looked gorgeous on the PSP, and fans are glad that this game has been remastered with modern and updated controls for modern consoles.

9 Persona 3 Portable

The Visual Novel Aesthetic Looks Great Even Now

Persona 3 was the game that catapulted the popularity of this series to the stratosphere. However, Atlus believed that this series had way more potential and decided to re-release an updated version of the game on the PSP.

The end result was Persona 3 Portable , a game that made the most of the PSP's limited hardware and has finally been ported over to modern consoles. The game adopts a visual novel aesthetic to make up for the PSP's lack of power and looks pretty gorgeous regardless, with the addition of a new protagonist being welcomed by the fanbase.

8 Final Fantasy Tactics: The War Of The Lions

A Beloved PS1 Game That Looks Even Better On The PSP

Final Fantasy Tactics is one of the greatest tactical role-playing games of all time. So, it's only a given that an updated version of this game would turn some heads.

The 2D art style has aged like a fine wine and still looks amazing today, with the tight gameplay still holding up quite well. All in all, Final Fantasy Tactics: The War of the Lions is probably the best Final Fantasy spin-off around that fans should definitely check out.

7 Lumines 2

A Flashy Art Style That Makes This Puzzle Game A Visual Treat For The Ages

  • Platforms : PSP
  • Release Date : November 2006
  • Developer : Q Entertainment, Bandai
  • Genre : Puzzle

The idea of a matching puzzle game making this list sounds downright ridiculous, but it's the amazing set dressing around this title that makes it such a blast to play through. The first Lumines game was a joy to play through, with its outpouring of colors and music making for a great time.

Lumines 2 expands on this concept even more, adding a ton of content into the mix to make any fan of the title enjoy their time with the game. The music choices may not be up everyone's alley, but most players who get lost in this amazing celebration of sound and visuals won't mind it at all!

6 Jeanne d'Arc

An SRPG With Visuals That Have Aged Like A Fine Wine

Another tactical JRPG makes its way on the list in the form of Jeanne d'Arc . The title combines real-life historical figures and a fantasy setting to great effect. It helps that the 2D art style of this game is timeless and still looks amazing even today.

Many veterans of tactical JRPGs consider this game to be one of the most underappreciated games in the entire genre and one that more people need to check out.

5 Tactics Ogre: Let Us Cling Together

An Updated Version Of A Classic SRPG With Great Visuals

Tactics Ogre is a part of the lesser-known Ogre Battle series, with Let Us Cling Together being a pretty fun title on the Super Nintendo. The release of its remaster, Tactics Ogre: Reborn , on modern platforms, has been a welcome sight for fans of this niche title.

Most of these fans came from the release of this title on the PSP, with the game looking pretty great on this platform, too. Of course, it helped that the strategic gameplay of this title was quite fun as well!

4 Patapon 3

A 2D Game With Memorable Visual Design

  • Platforms : PSP
  • Release Date : April 2011
  • Developer : Japan Studio
  • Genre : Rhythm Game

It's only a given that 2D games on the PlayStation Portable would age nicely. Patapon 3 definitely fits in this category, with its rhythm-based gameplay being a ton of fun to play through.

The idea of playing drums with the PSP's face buttons and controlling an army of Patapons is a pretty novel and fun concept that the game absolutely rolls with. Patapon 3 is an underrated gem indeed, and players looking for a unique rhythm game should definitely check this title out.

3 God Of War: Ghost Of Sparta

A PSP God Of War Game With Some Impressive Visuals

The God of War games on the PS2 were pretty legendary, but no one expected these titles on the PSP to look as good as they did. Chains of Olympus was a great start for Santa Monica Studio, and Ghost of Sparta was a marked improvement on every front.

It was clear that the developers learned some tricks while working on the first PSP title since Ghost of Sparta looks incredible during certain moments. To this day, fans find it hard to believe that such a great title managed to run on the PSP without any hiccups!

2 LocoRoco 2

A Colorful Platformer That's Infinitely Charming To This Day

  • Platforms : PlayStation 4, PSP
  • Release Date : November 2008
  • Developer : Japan Studio, Sony Interactive Entertainment
  • Genre : Adventure, Platformer, Puzzle

LocoRoco 2 is one of the most unique platforming games around and a great sequel that improves upon the original while adding several new features of its own. It helps that its clean 2D aesthetic helped the game age quite well and makes it infinitely playable to this day.

The fact that players need to tilt the environment to manipulate the LocoRocos and help them pass certain obstacles makes for a simple yet great gameplay loop. The sequel lets LocoRocos squeeze through tiny gaps, swim underwater, and perform various other functions to make the platforming challenges more dynamic and interesting.

1 Final Fantasy Type-0

An Addition To This Beloved Series With Great Visuals That Look Great Even Now

Another Final Fantasy title makes its way on this list in the form of Final Fantasy Type-0 . Set in the Fabula Nova Crystallis universe, Final Fantasy Type-0 features a pretty mature story that depicts the brutality and senselessness of war.

The graphics are amazing, and Western fans were glad to finally play this game when the remastered edition came out on the PS4. The ending is an emotional gut punch, with the game's beautiful CG cutscenes further contributing to its timelessness.
